titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Went to Amsterdam by the morning post-waggon; arrived there between one and two o’clock. after Dinner Mr: William Willink and Mr: Hubbard called on me, and informed me they had agreed Mr: Hubbard should go to England there to make arrangements relative to the funds of the United States received by Mr: Pinckney, and destined for the payment of monies which will become due here in June.— This plan appears to me very difficult of execution, and objectionable in many respects. I mentioned most of the objections and found them decided. Mr: William Willink intimated to me that they considered all the responsibility of the business to rest upon them. From this determination I endeavoured to avert them by urging an attempt to the renewal of the instalment. Mr: Willink finally declared explicitly, that they would not undertake that, without an express order from me in writing, to make a sacrifice of ten per cent as a premium for renewal. I answered that I should certainly give no such order, and indeed that I could give them no orders on the subject. Mr: Willink was going immediately into the Country, and desired us to dine with him there to-morrow, in order to make the necessary arrangements. Mr: Bourne called on us, as did Mr: G. W. Erving, who came very lately from London, and whom I was somewhat surprized to find in this Country.

2. Went to Haerlem with Mr: Hubbard. Dined at Mr: William Willink’s Country seat, & drank tea at his brother John’s. The name of the former is Bosch en Hoven; that of the latter Bosch en Vaart. They are handsome, though not magnificent houses, with gardens according to the common custom of the Country. That of Mr: William Willink cost him with the repairs he found necessary nearly an hundred thousand Guilders. Its annual expence to him must be of two or three thousand; it gives him no income whatever. “If there is a luxury said he this day; it is a Country seat.” Such is the common opinion here, and people who unite the greatest wealth, with an oeconomy that in every other country would be called parcimonious indulge in this luxury to an excess unknown elsewhere, in this luxury. They generally spend the Saturday and Sunday throughout the year, at the Country seat, and the remainder of the week in the City drudging for the accumulation of enormous wealth. The Gardens have nothing remarkably agreeable; every thing is cut up and fashioned by the rule and square. The hot houses appear to be the most useful part. We saw ha. . . strawberry’s in their state of full maturity, apricots half ripe, and peaches of the size of a walnut. The wall fruit trees are covered every night during this Season with double mats of reeds, and of flags.— We returned to Amsterdam in the Evening, having as an addition to our company a french Gentlemen, whom we found at Mr: John Willink’s—

3. Mr: Bourne called on us this forenoon. At 1. we again set out in the Stage coach for the Hague, where we arrived at about 9 in the Evening. Found upon arrival a letter from the Secretary of the Treasury January 25. and several from my mother.

4. Busy in writing all day for Mr: Hubbard. To my father; to Mr: Pinckney, Mr: Johnson. Secy: of the Treasury. Walk in the wood; met & walk’d with Messrs: Middleton, Brito and Bielfeld. Visit from Mr: Van Staphorst in the morning.
5. Writing again to send by Mr: Hubbard, Secretary of State— purchased some books this afternoon. Long walk with a Spanish Gentleman; his name as yet unknown to me.

6. Mr: Hubbard called on me this morning very early intending to set out on his voyage to England. Delivered to him all the papers I had prepared for him, and he set out. Walk in the wood at noon. When I came home, I found a billet from Mr: N. Van Staphorst enclosing one from Hubbard to him, informing him that he was arrested, and Mr: Van Staphorst’s requesting me to go with him to the commander of the place, and obtain his release. I could not go to obtain his release from a french military officer, but being desirous to take every proper measure in the case, and at least to know the cause of his detention, I went immediately to the lodgment of Amsterdam, found Mr: Van Staphorst at dinner, and soon after went with him to General Delmas the present commander, recently substituted for Dumonceau. Upon enquiring what was the cause of Mr: Hubbard’s arrest, the General said it was because he was going to England, a thing prohibited and therefore suspicious. Because he had a Passport from the States General dated but two days ago, and inspected by the representative Ramel, who had been a fortnight in Paris, Mr: Van Staphorst told him that it was because their High Mightinesses had received several signatures of Ramel, upon blank Passports, for mutual accomodation. Delmas said that he knew nothing about that; but the circumstance had been so suspicious, and heightened by an attempt to go without having presented the Passport for his visa as was necessary, that he had thought his duty obliged him to order the arrest, and to send the Papers that had been found on Mr: Hubbard to the General in Chief of the Northern Army. That he could not now undo what was done, and the arrest must continue until he should receive his Answer. From thence Mr: Van Staphorst went to the commandant of the police Soder, in whose custody Hubbard was. I told him that in a case where there was a misunderstanding of arrangements agreed on between the french Representatives and this Government my interference would obviously be improper, and that I must therefore retire. Came home accordingly.— In the Evening feeling however very anxious that Hubbard should suffer this treatment when employed upon business of the United States, I wrote a line to Mr: Van Staphorst again requesting to know when I could see him; he desired me in answer to come immediately to the Hall where the States General were assembled, and which he could
not quit; he there told me that Mr: Hubbard was at the Heeren Logement, and that a second express had been sent to Utrecht upon the business. Called at the Heeren Logement to see Hubbard, and found him with a french soldier in his chamber.— Visit from Mr: Scholten. billet relative to quartering soldier’s in Mr: Greenleaf’s house.
7. No Answer from Utrecht relative to Hubbard’s business, this day. Called again to see him this Evening; found Mr: J. Van Staphorst with him.

8. Mr Van Staphorst again sent me word that the Representative Alquier had arrived here with all Hubbard’s papers, and requesting me again to go with him at 4 o’clock, to Alquier upon the subject. I called on him at 4 o’clock, and told him, that as the Reason given by the commanding Officer for his conduct towards Hubbard, originated simply in a mistake in arrangements made between the french Representatives and the States General, from respect for both parties I should not interfere in the matter and could not therefore with propriety go with him. On returning home I wrote a card to the Representative Alquier to know when I could see him. It was received from my servant by one of the Secretaries who said he could not deliver it immediately Alquier being very much engaged; but would as soon as possible and promised an answer for to-morrow. A few minutes after, Mr: Hubbard called to take my commands for Amsterdam; he had just been delivered, and had his pocket-book containing his papers returned to him the seals untouched. He has determined from the first moment to return home, and not proceed upon his voyage to England.

Mr: Girard and Mr: Van Rensselaer both from Amsterdam called on me this morning. Walk at noon with Bielfeld. Evening at Mr: Scholten’s.— Played at Cassino with Madam Nederburg, the Baron de Spaen, & Mr: Reutenswerd. Mr: De Schubart there, the latter part of the Evening. Came this day from Amsterdam through Utrecht. The Evening such as usual. Madam Nederburg not quite so poetical. Two other ladies were also of the company. They were unknown to me, and had nothing to excite extraordinary curiosity.

9. Visit this morning to Mr: Van Rensselaer. He dined with us, together with Bielfeld. Evening at the french Comedy.— Directeur dans l’Embarras. Deux Petits Savoyards. Company rather better than indifferent. Met Messrs: Middleton & Brito at the Play. Last Evening it seems Syeyes and Rewbell two members of the Committee of Public Safety of France, arrived here from Paris. The Representatives Alquier, Cochon, Richard and Ramel, who had before been here in mission likewise arrived. The General in Chief of the Northern Army came at the same time.— Brito says the members from the Committee of public safety have come to do the counterpart of the Alliance made here by Sir William Temple. He was answered that they would not easily find a De Witt to
treat with. The States General have however appointed a deputation of four members to confer with them.
10. Mr: Van Rensselaer left the place for Amsterdam. Walk in the wood with Baron Bielfeld. met likewise M: Brito. Wrote Secretary of the Treasury.

11. Met this forenoon in walking Mr: Middleton, who said he was well in the body; mais bien malade de l’esprit. He is much distressed for the fate of his Country, and finds himself here in an embarassing situation.— Card this afternoon to the french Representatives just arrived, to know when I could see them. A formality which I do not willingly perform, but which is made necessary to me.
12. Answer from the french Representatives that they will see me to morrow at ten in the morning. Sat this afternoon to Mr: Parker, an English Painter for a miniature I have promised to my mother.

13. Sat again early in the morning. At ten went according to appointment & saw the Representatives Rewbell and Sieyes. Met Baron Bielfeld going at the same time. Conversation with Sieyes of about a quarter of an hour. He made a number of questions relative to the Treaty, signed by Mr: Jay with the British Minister last November. The answers he received were in a style similar to that of the questions, and terminated with the information that the only public article is one which provides that the Treaty shall not interfere with any previous engagement of either party.— After returning home, I finished my sitting, and then took a walk with Bielfeld.— Went to the Dutch play in the Evening, & saw Alzire, and the Deux petits Savoyards translated, performance indifferent. Met a french man there, who came not long since from Paris. He talked very much in the same style with the rest. Called the partizans of Robespierre, by no other name than gueusards and gredins. And said that their Revolution had been useful in destroying the exclusive privileges of the nobility and of farmers general.
14. Endeavoured to be very busy in writing. Walk solitary; returning saw Bielfeld for a moment. Time flies and is at the same time yet very heavy.

15. Writing again most of the day: met my Spanish companion this morning in the wood. At the Dutch play this Evening. The Royal Slave an original Dutch Tragedy, and Blaise et Babet. The Tragedy was scarcely tolerable; and the opera itself was nearly tedious.

16. Day again past as yesterday. Met Mr: Levsen walking. Evening from excess of ennui at the play again. Did not see the Tragedy, but only the farce of Taylor & his Son; a translation from the German.

17. Weather beautiful. Walk in the forenoon and towards Sunset: met Mr: Brito both Times. he informed me that the Treaty between France and this Country was signed this morning at two o’clock, as also of its principal articles.
18. Met again my Spanish friend in the wood. Flower market full of Company. Mr: Bourne dined with us. Dutch play, Tartuffe, and a little opera. The marriage of Antonio.

19. Mr: Bourne went to Rotterdam. Letter to Secy: of State. A task constantly returning must degenerate into drudgery. Mr: George Lane a Bostonian here this Evening. Shew us papers to the 1st: of April from Boston. Another setting this afternoon to Mr: Parker the miniature Painter. —Fire ext:
20. Bielfeld called to see me, and we walked in the wood. Mr: Bourne returned from Rotterdam. Goes to Amsterdam to-morrow. Evening an hour or two at Mr: Veerman’s, conversation with Madam alone.
21. Weather warm. Walking in the wood. Mr Bourne went to Amsterdam. Walk again towards night. Writing Letters. Dulness doubly dull.

22. Party this Evening at Baron Schubart’s. Company numerous, french, Dutch, English, besides the diplomatic varieties. Two young Ladies from Utrecht by the name of Westreen particularly remarkable. With their mother now on a visit at the Barons Play’d at Quadrill with one of them. Talks incessantly. Conversation with M. Faujas de St: Fond, the french Philosopher who follows the army to collect objects of curiosity for the use of the Nation. Seems to be as much Petit maitre as philosopher. Escaped from the company before supper.

23.— Writing Letters. At the Dutch play this Evening. House very full. Joan van Olden Barneveld a tragedy in three acts, the subject national. The sentiments of the fashionable kind, very much applauded. A very stupid occasional ballet upon the alliance lately concluded, finishing with an ode, that was applauded of course. The french comic opera Felix was given for the termination. Between 11 & 12, before it was over.

24. Walk in the wood, met Mr: Brito. Mr: Middleton & Baron Bielfeld. Evening at the Comte Löwenhielm’s; company smaller than at the Baron’s last, & therefore more agreeable. Play’d Quadrill again with the elder Mlle: Westreen. At supper between two Braband ladies emigrants, who hated the french; hated the Dutch; hated the Hague, and were sure the Emperor would never abandon them. One of them appeared to have beaucoup d’esprit.— Visit this morning from Mr: Hubbard.

25. Called on Mr: Parker and saw some of his paintings. Walk in the wood. Met Mr: Levsen. Evening an hour or two at Madam Veerman’s. Monsieur who is an Officer in the national guards came in from his exercises. Seems to take a satisfaction in his new employment.

26. Weather very cold. uncomfortable climate. Walk in the wood in the forenoon. At 5. afternoon, went to see the exercising of the national guard. Their appearance very well. Met there Messrs: Midleton, Bielfeld and Brito.
27. Weather still cold. Walk alone. Evening at the french play. Paul et Virginie. Les quatres Coins—indifferent. Met there the gentlemen above-mentioned.

28. Cold. Met and walked with Mr: Levsen. Reading Dufresnoy’s art of Painting, translated by Mason with the Commentary of Sir Joshua Reynolds. a book lent me by Mr: Parker. Visit this morning from young Jeffrey, not long since from America, and from Mr: Campbell & Mr: M’Callum, likewise American Citizens.— French play. Epreave Villageoise. Deux Suisses ou la pieté filiale. Musical. the last Revolutionary. Ballet des Quakers. Mr: Midleton & Mr: Brito.

30. Very cold still. Walk in the wood. Met Mr: Levsen. french Comedy at night—Raoul de Crequi, and Les deux Suisses. first piece interesting. Music mediocre. music of second very good; rest bad. House tolerably full. Met Mrs: Middleton, Brito & Bielfeld, who introduced to me his brother just arrived from Paris.— Mr: Parker here at the close of the Evening. Conversation with him upon the subject of painting.

31. Walk in the morning. Met the Messrs: Bielfeld, Brito, Midleton, & the Spaniard. Weather begins to grow more tolerable. Walk afternoon in the wood, considerable company. Met Mr: Dedem, the father. Talked of the news of the day.— Visit in the Evening from Messrs: T. H. Perkins, and J. Russell, came this day from Amsterdam.
